items.author: Richard Corliss
items.content: The film is seductive, disturbing, enthralling -- a trip to hell that gives the passengers a great ride.

items.author: Megan Lehmann
items.content: Like a bomb exploding in a fireworks factory: It's fierce and shocking and dazzling and wonderful.

items.author: Marjorie Baumgarten
items.content: A marvelous achievement that refuses to avert its gaze from the poetry and the insane savagery of the hopeless.

items.author: Stephen Holden
items.content: As the movie's frenetic visual rhythms and mood swings synchronize with the zany, adrenaline-fueled impulsiveness of its lost youth on the rampage, you may find yourself getting lost in this teeming netherworld.

items.author: William Arnold
items.content: It takes a strong stomach to sit through its two-plus hours of non-stop brutality (much of it involving very small children).

items.author: Kenneth Turan
items.content: A potent and unexpected mixture of authenticity and flash -- even if this is what happened on the ground, making it worth our time on screen is just beyond the contortionist abilities of even this most acrobatic of films.

items.author: Anthony Lane
items.content: Meirelles's picture is so keen to brandish its social wrath, and its spirits are so rampagingly high, that the bruises it inflicts barely last a night. [20 January 2003, p. 94]

items.author: Wesley Morris
items.content: Full of action, but no soul.

items.author: David Sterritt
items.content: In its cinematic approach, though, the film is as slick as any Hollywood thriller, directed by Fernando Meirelles with visual flourishes - jazzy editing, lurid colors, crackling sound effects - that dilute the impact of what might have been an indelible cautionary tale.

items.author: Peter Rainer
items.content: Undeniably powerful, but also rather numbing.
